https://prez.dev/description.@value: The study of the history, composition, relative ages and distribution of strata, and the interpretation of strata to elucidate Earth history. The comparison, or correlation, of separated strata can include study of their lithology, fossil content, and relative or absolute age, or lithostratigraphy, biostratigraphy, and chronostratigraphy. Source: Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary
The subject is an instance of a class.
The defininition of the subject resource.
An idea or notion; a unit of thought
Relates a concept to a concept that is more general in meaning
A statement or formal explanation of the meaning of a concept

skos:exactMatch is used to link two concepts, indicating a high degree of confidence that the concepts can be used interchangeably across a wide range of information retrieval applications. skos:exactMatch is a transitive property, and is a sub-property of skos:closeMatch
A note about the past state/use/meaning of a concept
Relates a resource (for example a concept) to a concept scheme in which it is included
Relates a concept to a concept that is more specific in meaning
A notation, also known as classification code, is a string of characters such as 'T58.5' or '303.4833' used to uniquely identify a concept within the scope of a given concept scheme
The preferred lexical label for a resource, in a given language

https://prez.dev/label.@value: 1297.0 ANZSRC - Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification, 2020: Fields of Research (FoR)
Stratigraphy (incl. biostratigraphy, sequence stratigraphy and basin analysis)

https://prez.dev/description.@value: A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

The element of stratigraphy that deals with the distribution of fossils in the stratigraphic record and the organization of strata into units on the basis of their contained fossils, specifically to date and correlate strata to elucidate Earth's history. In the petroleum industry, biostratigraphy often denotes the use of terrestrial (pollen and spores) and marine (diatoms, foraminifera, nanofossils) microfossils to determine the numerical or relative age and depositional environment of a particular formation, source rock, or reservoir of interest.

Chemostratigraphy, or chemical stratigraphy, is the study of the chemical signatures and their variations within lithological sequences to determine stratigraphic relationships. It includes the element of stratigraphy that deals with chemical signals as recorded in the stratigraphic record to identify spatialâ€“temporal variations in the concentration and distribution of particular elements and isotopes (e.g. carbonate cycles and isotope cycles).
The branch of stratigraphy that deals with the age of strata and their time relations.

The element of stratigraphy that deals with the description and systematic organization of the rocks of the Earth's crust into distinctive named units based on the lithological character of the rocks and their stratigraphic relations. In the petroleum industry, lithostratigraphy specifically refers to the study and correlation of strata to elucidate Earth's history on the basis of their lithology or the nature of the well log response, mineral content, grain size, texture, and colour of rocks.

The element of stratigraphy that deals with the magnetic characteristics of rock units. Specifically the geophysical correlation technique used to date sedimentary rocks lacking fossils and volcanic sequences by collecting oriented samples at measured intervals throughout a section and measuring the characteristic remanent magnetization.

The study of stratigraphy and depositional facies as interpreted from seismic data; an integrated stratigraphic and sedimentologic technique to interpret seismic reflection data for stratigraphic correlation and to predict depositional environments and lithology.

The study of rock relationships within a chronostratigraphic framework of repetitive, genetically related strata bounded by surfaces of erosion or nondeposition, or their correlative conformities (Van Wagoner et al., 1990). Specifically, a field of study in which basin-filling sedimentary deposits, called sequences, are interpreted in a framework of eustasy, sedimentation and subsidence through time in order to correlate strata and predict the stratigraphy of relatively unknown areas.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The study of the history, composition, relative ages and distribution of strata, and the interpretation of strata to elucidate Earth's history. The comparison, or correlation, of separated strata can include study of their form, distribution, lithology, fossil content, geophysical and geochemical properties, relative or numerical/absolute age, and their interpretation in terms of environment or mode of origin, and geological history.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf, 2011).

A citation or reference to another creative work, such as another publication, web page, scholarly article, etc
